entry.title: BrSupply Suprimientos Corporativos Punchout Integration to SAP BTP CPI
entry.content:
Hello, I have the following scenario.

Our company developed a SAP FIORI UI5 application which runs on the cloud foundry environment. From this app, the user is lead to a punchout catalogue. The process is something like this :

1. Hit punchout button
2. A request is sent to an oData service exposed from S4H (on-premise)
3. oData calls CPI
4. CPI calls external provider which returns a url, this is url is the punchout catalogue site that is returned to the UI5 appication.
5. UI5 application uses this url an open a new browser tab.

And here is where the problem is happening


The url which is opened in the browser belongs to an external site (punchout catalogue), from there the user calls an API REST endpoint exposed in SAP BTP CPI, we already provide the credentials to the provider admin to authenticate to the BTP but they state they aren't able to send the credentials and for sure they aren't able to complete the purchase process from the punchout site. Have you guys ever worked on an integration like so, I mean , punchout catalogue to SAP BTP CPI? The API REST exposed by cpi internally calls an oData service, I was wondering if this integration isn't posible (punchout ---- cpi) , is it possible to expose the s4 hanna service to the provider (punchout- catalogue) without using CPI. S4H in this case is on-premise

 

Hope this is clear, if you have any questions let me know.

entry.title: XPRAS Error During MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG in S/4HANA Conversion Execution Phase
entry.content:
During the recent Oracle → HANA system conversion to S/4HANA 2023, we encountered an error in the Execution Phase where SUM stopped with an error at the step MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG.

Overview

During the SUM execution, the process stopped in MAIN_NEWBAS/XPRAS_AIMMRG due to BW-related inconsistencies. The phase could not continue because certain BW InfoObjects were not fully activated before downtime.

 

Analysis

  • While reviewing the error logs (XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG and related BW activation logs), we observed multiple failures related to InfoObject activation.
  • The XPRAS engine failed to merge certain BW objects because the BW content was not in an active state before SUM was started.
  • We validated client settings, checked multiple profiles, reviewed shadow logs, and compared BW content activation status before correlating this with the root cause.
  • Only after detailed log review and cross-checking, it became clear that the system required specific BW preparation activities prior to downtime.

How to Identify

These indicators helped confirm the issue early:

  1. XPRAS error in XPRASUPG_NEW.ELG with BW InfoObject activation entries.
  2. Multiple failed entries referring to missing or inactive InfoObjects.
  3. BW task list not executed before downtime (SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA).
  4. Running STC01 or RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE manually showed several inactive objects.
  5. SUM repeating the same activation attempts and stopping again.

This combination confirmed that BW content activation was incomplete prior to the conversion.

Resolution

After confirming the root cause, we performed the below steps to fix the issue:

  1. Implemented the required corrections in Client 000 using a non-DDIC user with SAP_ALL.
  2. Activated the missing BW InfoObjects as per SAP Note 3315495.
  3. Ensured the system was locked again and resumed the SUM execution.
  4. SUM continued successfully without further XPRAS errors.

Workaround (for early detection )

To prevent the issue in the next conversion cycles (QA/DR/Production):

  • Implement SAP Notes 3305016 and 3316148 before executing SUM.
    • Before downtime, run task list:
    STC01 → SAP_BW_SETUP_INITIAL_S4HANA
  • Optionally run:
    Program RSDG_IOBJ_ACTIVATE to ensure all InfoObjects are active.
  • Validate BW readiness in Sandbox during rehearsal runs.

These actions ensure the BW layer is fully consistent before SUM execution begins.

Regards,
Shubham Mishra

entry.title: Generic XI Outbound flow in Cloud Integration Pipeline
entry.content:
With the latest version update 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration package, we have added a generic XI outbound processing flow Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI. It's shipped with the integration package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound. You can use the generic XI outbound flow for both asynchronous as well as synchronous communication using the XI message protocol. See Introducing a new version 1.0.1 of the Pipeline for Cloud Integration packages.

Intro

The generic XI outbound processing flow is actually not replacing the scenario-specific outbound flow (Step 07), it is an additional step (Step 08) in the rows of pipeline steps for handling the connection to receiver systems using the XI protocol. So, in step 07 you define your scenario-specific mappings and then call step 08 via ProcessDirect adapter. Step 08 acts then as XI receiver channel to dynamically connecting to the backend systems.

This new feature was done per customer's request to standardize and ease the configuration of XI outbound scenarios. With this, you are able to dynamically connect to the backend, set monitoring headers in a common way, and store adapter connectivity logic in one place.

It was also done because we quite often noticed that the XI receiver adapter was wrongly setup in terms of delivery assurance. In the new XI outbound processing integration flow, the delivery assurance in the receiver adapter is properly setup using the UniqueID header which is passed from the pipeline. By default, the UniqueID equals the Message Processing Log ID of the generic outbound processing flow (Step 06) which takes care of dispatching messages to the scenario-specific flows and eventually restarting failed messages. You also have the option to modify the UniqueID header in the scenario-specific outbound flow if you prefer to use a unique ID from the message payload. In any case, a unique ID will be automatically used by the XI receiver adapter ensuring Exactly Once delivery.

Configuration Options

As said, you dynamically configure the XI receiver adapter parameters and the XI header attributes during runtime. For this, different options are supported as outlined in the XI Receiver Adapter help documentation. Combining the options is also supported.

  • You can create and maintain message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow (Step 07).
  • You can create and maintain the parameters in the Partner Directory.
  • You can configure the externalized parameters of the generic XI outbound integration flow (Step 08).

We distinguish between XI connection parameters and XI message headers (scenario related).

  • Because XI headers are scenario-specific (e.g. Service Interface name), you would configure them either as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow or as string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the configuration scenario.
  • The configuration of connection parameters depends on your chosen approach. You may define receiver-specific XI outbound flows by copying the Cloud Integration Pipeline – Generic Outbound package. This allows you to create an individual XI Step 08 flow for each XI receiver and in this case, you would configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied generic XI outbound integration flow. Otherwise, if you used one single generic XI outbound integration flow across all scenarios and all receivers, you would maintain string parameters in the Partner Directory for the partner ID representing the business component or configure them as message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow Step 07.

Sample Scenario

This blog post intends to explain the different options in more detail along sample scenarios. In the Partner Directory, we have setup a configuration scenario of pattern Content-Based-Router with 2 sender systems and 3 receiver systems. On the Alternative Partners tab, we map the sender system names, the sender interface name and the sender interface namespace to our configuration scenario, here CS_PIP_Samples_Scenario_02E. Actually, on the sender side we also use the XI protocol, so those parameters are part of the XI header of the message sent to Cloud Integration. In the generic XI inbound flow we then determine the partner ID of the configuration scenario based on the alternative partner defined.

Each receiver is differently configured to be able to cover all options mentioned above. On tab Binary Parameters, we have uploaded a binary containing the XSLT which is carried out to determine the receivers based on XPath conditions.

In the XSLT, you can see that for the 3 receivers we call different scenario-specific outbound processing flows.

Option 1: Message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow

The first receiver, in our case BS_02E_R1, uses the first option by maintaining message headers in the scenario-specific outbound processing flow. As you can see below, the ProcessDirect endpoint of the scenario-specific outbound processing flow is the one maintained in the XSLT in case that the supplier equals ABCD and the country equals DE.

In a content modifier step, we have maintained the connection parameters like credential alias, authentication method, proxy type and XI endpoint of the receiver system as well as the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline. Optionally, you can override them here. All message headers are then passed to the generic XI outbound flow. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

We then call the generic XI outbound flow via ProcessDirect adapter. Here, we need to enter the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow.

By default, the endpoint of the generic XI outbound flow equals /generic/step08/xi. You can change to your own preferences. We kept the default.

Finally, we sent a sample message to the pipeline. In the message monitor you find all log entries that belong to the same exchanged message. You can filter on the log entries by selecting the Correlation ID link. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

By the way, the actual sender and receiver names are BS_02E_S1Q and BS_02E_R1Q, respectively, because we run the scenario on the Quality Assurance environment. Those names are then mapped to alias names which are used within the pipeline, e.g., in the XSLT. See next chapter where we show how to setup the support for different landscape stages for the involved business systems.

 

Option 2: Parameters in the Partner Directory

The second receiver, here BS_02E_R2, uses the second option by maintaining the Partner Directory parameters. The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that the supplier equals EFGH and for any country other than DE. Here, we do not need to create any message headers and we forward the message to the generic XI outbound flow with default endpoint like in the option before.

As mentioned above, you can maintain both in the Partner Directory XI headers and connection parameters. For the connection parameters we need to define a partner ID representing the business system. We need this anyway to map from the actual business system name to the alias name. We actually did this for all systems involved in the configuration scenarios. As an example the screenshot below shows the partner ID with the alias name BS_02E_R2. In the Alternative Partners tab, we map the actual names to the alias depending on the landscape stage, e.g., for QA the actual name is BS_02E_R2Q. If you like to know more about how to setup the support for different landscape stages, check out Landscape Stages.

On the String Parameters tab of the System Alias, we have maintained the XI connection parameters i.e. proxy type, authentication method, credential alias, and XI endpoint of the receiver system. The naming convention is to add the actual system name as suffix to the parameter names. Here, we only did this for the QA landscape, usually you would then also maintain the string parameters for the other landscapes. By the way, this business system alias can be used across different configuration scenarios and hence you can reuse those connection settings. For the detailed parameter names, refer to XI Receiver Adapter.

The XI headers are scenario-specific and hence they are maintained as string parameters of the configuration scenario. For the InterfaceNameDetermination parameter add the receiver system alias as suffix. For the InterfaceNamespaceDetermination parameter add the interface name that you defined before as suffix (the namespace can also be determined dynamically in Step 08 by evaluating an XPath expression against the XML payload; however, this requires that the payload’s namespace matches the namespace of the corresponding Service Interface). The other XI headers SAP_SenderParty, SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface, SAP_ReceiverParty and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc. Here we actually also use a party for the receiver system, see XSLT above.

 

Option 3: Configuring the generic XI outbound integration flow

The third receiver, here BS_02E_R3, uses the third option i.e. an own generic XI outbound integration flow. In this case, we need to create a copy of the generic XI outbound integration flow and configure the connection parameters as externalized parameters of the copied flow. It is important not to directly copy the integration flow but rather copy the standard package Cloud Integration Pipeline - Generic Outbound that we provide on the SAP Accelerator Business Hub. This way, you ensure that the copied integration flow still receives updates if any.

So, in the Discover area of your tenant, search for the package and then select Copy.

In the upcoming dialog, you are informed that the package already exists, so select Create copy.

Then maintain a package suffix, here BS.02ER3 indicating that this is a business system specific package, then select OK. All integration flows of the copied package get the suffix added to their IDs as well.

When switching to the Design area, you should see the copied package.

In the copied package, configure the Pipeline v2 Generic Step08 - Outbound Processing for XI flow. Before you are able to deploy the flow, you need to change its ProcessDirect endpoint. This needs to be unique across the tenant.

Furthermore, on tab More we configure the XI connection parameters. Note, those are actually default values. They are only applied if not otherwise defined i.e. as message headers or in the Partner Directory. For this receiver, this is not the case so we ensure that those default values are used.

The corresponding scenario-specific outbound processing flow has the ProcessDirect endpoint configured as maintained in the XSLT above for the case that no receiver could be determined, see above.

We do need to at least maintain the XI headers SAP_ReceiverInterface and SAP_ReceiverInterfaceNamespace as message headers. The headers SAP_Sender, SAP_SenderInterface and SAP_Receiver are already provided by the generic pipeline.

In order to call the copied generic XI outbound flow, we need to enter its ProcessDirect endpoint as configured above.

When sending a sample message to the pipeline, you can monitor the exchanged message in the message monitor. The Properties section and the Custom Headers section shows relevant details such as actual sender and receiver name, sender and receiver alias, receiver interface and namespace as maintained in the flow above, quality of service, etc.

Unfortunately, the copied XI outbound flow name is kept unchanged. You need to scroll down to the Artifacts Details section to see its integration flow ID which contains the suffix.

Hope this helps you set up your XI outbound scenarios using the new generic XI outbound flow of the Cloud Integration Pipeline. If you are missing any XI-specific processing capabilities that would be useful for such a generic XI receiver flow, feel free to share your thoughts in the comments.

Good to Know

Outbound processing for XI is designed around the XI receiver adapter’s capability to manage Quality of Service at the Integration Flow level. When this processing mode is enabled, the outbound connection can only be created from a Message End event. This means that Request-Reply or Send steps cannot be used, and the XI call will always appear as the final processing step in the main integration process. Because of this limitation, it is not possible to set custom headers containing the XI Message ID generated in the receiver XI system for end-to-end tracking. To address this, we recommend adding a Content Modifier in your Step 07 to store custom headers with the XI Message ID and then attach these headers to the message processing log using the script from the Pipeline v2 - Script Collection.

entry.title: Re: How to customize push notification payload to send additional data from s/4 to SSAM
entry.content: @daniyal_dolare I tested via IW21 in SAP GUI, Create Maintenance Request in Fiori, and Create Maintenance Notification in Fiori. In all scenarios I see the notification in the table by the time BUILD_JSON_DATA is executed. If this truly won't work for you, another option is to change the criteria that triggers the push. If you trigger the push when the notification is put in process or approved rather than created you should have access to the data you want. You can control this via the SAMXXXX_NOTIFICATION_PUSH exchange object.

entry.title: Re: BTP service plan "Process Integration Runtime" and Cl...
entry.content:
In Integration Suite there are only 2 commercial metrics

1) Tenant cost (flat fixed cost to "turn on" Integration Suite

2) Message cost (dynamic cost based on consumption)

Cloud Foundry (CF) is the underlying platform for BTP Multi-Cloud, and you are "enabling" the related access points in CF to be made available (e.g. CF CLI APIs). This has no cost as it is merely enabling access. 

Once this has been done, you can activate the Process Integration Runtime service, which is again, a part of the CF governance mechanism, to generate Service Keys for access to the runtime. There is no cost to be able to access your service.

Hope this helps others as well.

Regards,
Elijah

entry.title: Re: EWM Goods receipt posting using POST EWM Goods receip...
entry.content:
Hi,

Error message is pretty straightforward, so most probably stock for that material/SN combination already exists, so I first suggest you double check that in Manage Floor Stock app. Otherwise, I suggest you raise a ticker for further investigation and support.

However, by your description, it seems to me you are running a Discrete / Production Order scenario in Work Center POD. This API /v1/inventory/ewmGoodsReceipts is the same as used in 'Goods Receipt' POD Plugin in 'Order POD' execution flow, mostly used for Process Industry/Order execution. For a Discrete Industry/Order execution flow, you might want to evaluate using Packing APIs, to perform the same steps you perform in Work Center POD using Packing POD Plugin instead.  See https://api.sap.com/api/sapdme_packingunit/resource/Packing.

If my answer was helpful, please consider accepting it as solution. Hope it helps! Br, Manoel

entry.title: Re: Problem with access to new SAP Cloud Application Stud...
entry.content:
Hello ruben-jimenez,

With the new SDK extension, there is no option to run multiple SDK versions in parallel inside VS2022.

As a result, only one version of the SDK extension can be active at a time. During the 2-week window between test and production upgrades, you must uninstall one version and install the other as needed, as you said.

Alternatively, if you are working with a team, different users can install different versions to work around this limitation. Your suggestion of using a VM or another computer is also a valid approach. 

Kind regards,
Thiago

Hi,

Quantity Confirmation can be sensitive to checks flagged in OPK4, see Quantity Confirmation for some details.

Out of the box, Quantity Confirmation POD Plugin in Order POD does not prevent over confirmation at all, so if you have this as a requirement, I suggest you consider custom development/extension possibilities.

Br, Manoel

entry.content:
Dear community,

We have several entities (company codes) and would like to confirm the procedure for closing the AA module in advance.

Step by step:

1/Run the last depreciation jobs on 12/31/N.

2/Run the AA closing job via Schedule Fixed Asset Accounting Jobs.

3/Change the year (2024 to 2025 in the lower section) in “Make company code settings.”

entry.title: SAP Inside Track Paraguay CDE 2025: SPAIDER Revolucionando Procesos con Inteligencia Artificial
entry.content:
El SAP Inside Track Paraguay #SITCDE2025 nos regaló una charla fascinante de la mano de Douglas Figueiredo, Socio y CTO de TEIA Connect, @Teia_Connect quien con más de 18 años de experiencia en proyectos SAP, nos presentó SPAIDER: una solución que está revolucionando la manera en que las empresas interactúan con sus sistemas mediante inteligencia artificial



Douglas compartió una visión clara: la inteligencia artificial debe generar valor real en el mundo empresarial. SPAIDER se enfoca en empoderar al usuario final para que ejecute actividades repetitivas y complejas usando simplemente lenguaje natural.

"La persona más importante en el sistema es el usuario final, y necesitamos darle autonomía para que pueda hacer sus actividades utilizando los motores de inteligencia artificial."

¿Qué es SPAIDER?
SPAIDER (SAP Process Artificial Intelligence Evolution Resolution) es un asistente virtual que conecta usuarios con sistemas SAP. El nombre fusiona ingeniosamente Teia (telaraña en portugués) con Spider (araña en inglés), representando cómo esta solución conecta todos los elementos del ecosistema empresarial a través de un chat intuitivo.


Los Cuatro Pilares de SPAIDER
SPAIDER-eDOCS: Gestiona automáticamente documentos fiscales electrónicos, emitiendo más de 30 tipos de documentos obligatorios, consultando XMLs y optimizando aprobaciones gubernamentales.
SPAIDER-MONI: Monitoreo inteligente que supervisa aspectos técnicos y de negocio, alertando proactivamente sobre problemas antes de que impacten las operaciones.
SPAIDER-ESPEC: Genera especificaciones funcionales y prototipos mediante conversación natural, permitiendo que cualquier usuario documente requisitos sin conocimientos técnicos.
SPAIDER-TEST: Automatiza pruebas de regresión, ejecutando procesos completos y comparando valores con precisión del 100%. Genera evidencias en PDF para validación de cambios.



Durante la presentación, Douglas mostró el poder del lenguaje natural con SPAIDER-TEST. Con un simple comando como "crear un pedido de venta normal", el sistema identifica el tipo de pedido, consulta la referencia, crea automáticamente todo el proceso (pedido, entrega, factura) y presenta los resultados de forma clara.
Cuando modificó intencionalmente un dato de material para simular un impacto fiscal, SPAIDER-TEST detectó automáticamente las diferencias, las cuantificó con precisión y generó un reporte comparativo. Todo esto sin escribir código ni navegar por múltiples transacciones SAP.


La Visión de Teia Connect
Lo más inspirador fue entender la filosofía de Teia Connect sobre IA: no reemplazar personas, sino empoderarlas. En Teia, todos utilizan IA diariamente, los candidatos deben demostrar cómo la usan, y cada producto se construye con esta tecnología. Como Douglas enfatizó: "La integración debe ser transparente para el usuario, sin necesidad de mirar múltiples transacciones."
El Mensaje Final
SPAIDER representa un cambio fundamental en la interacción con sistemas empresariales: democratizar el acceso para que cualquier usuario ejecute procesos complejos, liberar tiempo estratégico automatizando tareas repetitivas, y generar valor real usando IA para resolver problemas concretos de negocio.
¿Lo mejor? SPAIDER es modular y escalable, adaptándose a las necesidades específicas de cada empresa.

Un especial agradecimiento a Douglas Figueiredo por compartir su conocimiento y pasión por la innovación, demostrando cómo la inteligencia artificial puede transformar realmente los procesos empresariales. A Teia Connect por desarrollar soluciones que empoderan a los usuarios y generan valor tangible en el ecosistema SAP.

Gracias también al equipo organizador del SAP Inside Track Paraguay por hacer posible estos espacios de aprendizaje que fortalecen nuestra comunidad y nos mantienen a la vanguardia de la tecnología.

entry.title: Re: How to drop/delete attachment(s) from CPI message
entry.content:
The SAPNote 3240138 contains wrong code example. Correct syntax is (in time of my reply 😉) :

import com.sap.gateway.ip.core.customdev.util.Message def Message processData(Message message) { message.getAttachments().clear() message.getAttachmentWrapperObjects().clear() message.getAttachmentObjects().clear() return message }

entry.title: Everything My Mom Taught Me about Change Management for AI in Procurement
entry.content:
A Story about Change Done Right

Growing up, our dinner table conversations were a mix of stories about our day. My dad, a computer programmer for a large tech company, would talk about coding languages and mainframes, while my mom would share stories about her accounting role at a regional office for a global organization. Back then, I found myself leaning in whenever she talked about big changes happening at her office. 

What struck me, even as a kid, was a clear pattern: when changes were significant, her leadership team went above and beyond to make the office environment collaborative and supportive. They held town halls, brought in specialized trainers, and one memorable summer they even had an ice cream truck visit the office every Friday.  

I realize now that her leadership team understood something fundamental, which is that successful change management isn’t just about rolling out new tools, it’s about considering the human impact. My mom happily worked for that organization for years and even recruited me to intern there. That’s the power of thoughtful change management. 

So how can you model what my mom experienced when implementing AI in SAP Ariba or SAP Fieldglass? Let's look at the playbook. 

Clear Communications: Everyone Deserves to Know the “Why” 

The first lesson from my mom's experience was transparency. Her leadership team didn't just announce changes, they explained the "why" behind their decisions and created multiple ways for employees to understand and engage.  

When you're implementing AI in procurement, develop a robust communication strategy that addresses where you're deploying it and the rationale behind those choices. Maybe you’re: 

  • Rolling out the AI-assisted SAP Ariba Category Management solution because it saves your team multiple hours per week by automating category analysis, enabling them to become strategic advisors with better data and faster identification of new business opportunities. 
  • Piloting intelligent resume analysis in SAP Fieldglass because it highlights top talent for hiring managers, giving them more time to focus on their core responsibilities while gaining a competitive advantage in talent acquisition. 

Be upfront about your reasoning. Use multiple communication channels that feel natural to your organization. Town halls work well for big-picture strategy and allowing open questions. "Ask Me Anything" sessions give employees a safe space to voice concerns. But don't stop there - weave updates into established channels like company newsletters, team meetings, and other standardized communications your teams already utilize and trust. 

Most importantly, identify and leverage internal champions early in your communication strategy. These trusted team members can help translate technical concepts into practical benefits and address concerns from their peers’ perspective. When your teams have questions, take the time to answer them thoughtfully. This isn't just courtesy; it's essential for adoption. 

Special Training Programs: Don't Skip This Step 

Here’s where many organizations stumble. They want to skip comprehensive training and assume people will figure out AI-driven tools on their own. Don’t make this mistake. 

First, Get Your Data Foundation Right 

Before you can train effectively, you need clean data. AI works best when the underlying data is structured, reliable, and consistently maintained, but many procurement organizations struggle with data that’s scattered across systems. Supplier names often vary between purchase orders and contracts and spend categories don’t align across business units. This fragmentation creates obstacles to adoption. 

That’s why you need to start by explaining how AI works within your solutions. When a user sees an AI-generated recommendation in SAP Ariba or an AI-generated statement of work (SOW) description in SAP Fieldglass, they should understand which data inputs created that content and why it matters.  

Then, Focus on User Training  

  • With Joule, show users how conversational AI accesses your organization’s information and best practices, demonstrating why instant access to critical data improves their decision-making capabilities 
  • With SAP Ariba, help users understand how market and historical data analysis creates real-time category strategy, supplier insights, and RFP recommendations, enabling them to make confident decisions and respond faster to changing conditions  
  • With SAP Fieldglass, explain how basic project inputs generate comprehensive descriptions for both job descriptions and SOWs, so hiring managers can trust AI-enhanced deliverables while focusing on strategic workforce planning 

Finally, Nurture and Support your Champions 

Your champions will help drive your success and should also be involved in validating AI recommendations during pilot phases. When they can vouch for the accuracy and usefulness of AI-generated insights, your solutions will be more impactful and their endorsement will carry a lot of weight, just like my mom’s feedback did at her organization. Keep your champions engaged by recognizing their contributions publicly, providing them with exclusive previews of new features, and regularly asking them for their input on product improvements. Personalized attention helps maintain their enthusiasm and advocacy.  

Your team won't automatically love new features just because they're AI-driven. You need to train them properly, communicate quick wins clearly, and continuously drive adoption.   

Ice Cream for Everyone: The Human Element Matters 

That summer, my mom made it her mission to try every flavor from that ice cream truck. She’d come home excited to tell us about both the ice cream and the wins, big and small, that her team was racking up with their new processes. And the best part? The changes let her spend more time digging into the more interesting, complex invoices instead of processing the easy ones that were never flagged.   

The small gestures mattered as much as the robust communication plans and training programs, creating an environment where change felt celebratory rather than threatening. 

Don't underestimate the human element that comes with any significant change. While AI-enabled solutions like SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass ensure there's always a human in the loop, people still feel natural apprehension about adopting tools that are designed to drive efficiency. They wonder if their expertise will still be valued, if their jobs will change, or if they'll be able to master new ways of working.  

Address this directly by highlighting how AI creates opportunities for greater visibility and strategic impact. For example:   

  • Joule eliminates information bottlenecks by making information conversationally accessible. It puts details like purchasing insights and hiring best practices at users’ fingertips. 
  • Sourcing and Bid Analysis Agents in SAP Ariba solutions reduce decision-making stress and increase agility by analyzing market and historical data to create and adapt RFPs in real time. This gives users confidence in purchasing decisions and faster responses to supply chain disruptions while freeing them to focus on negotiations and relationship building. 
  • The SAP Ariba Central Invoice Management solution elevates user roles by automating invoice processing where key thresholds are met. This reduces manual data entry so teams can focus on high-value exception management and build stronger vendor relationships. 
  • AI-assisted SOW creation tools in SAP Fieldglass applications streamline project planning by generating comprehensive descriptions from basic project inputs, enabling hiring managers to create detailed SOWs faster. The tools also drive consistency across templates and projects, which helps users shift from administrative workforce management to strategic talent optimization. 

The key is showing employees that AI elevates their expertise rather than replacing it, much like how my mom's new systems and processes made her work more strategic and less manual.  

Change Management Best Practices Actually Work 

Successful AI adoption follows the same change management approach that worked for my mom's organization years ago: clear communication, comprehensive training, genuine support, and celebration of progress. It’s a timeless template for transformation. 

  • Communicate clearly and frequently about what's changing and why. 
  • Invest in comprehensive training that's tailored for all skill levels. 
  • Create opportunities for feedback and iteration. 
  • Acknowledge that change is challenging and provide support.   

Most importantly, keep the human experience at the center of your implementation strategy. Technology should make people's work more interesting and valuable, not more complicated or uncertain.   

When procurement professionals can spend less time on data compilation and more time on strategic initiatives, have better insights to inform negotiations, and respond more quickly to business needs — that's when AI becomes fun and transformational.  

By getting this right, you ensure that your teams won't just adopt AI, they'll become advocates for it. They’ll share success stories and help scale the transformation across your organization, and they'll talk about how much fun they’re having at the dinner table, just like my mom did.  

Ready to optimize your company's approach to AI? Check out the AI-based solutions that are already embedded in your SAP Ariba and SAP Fieldglass applications on our SAP Business AI for procurement webpage.

entry.title: Kick-off SAP Community Belo Horizonte – Palestra com Alon Guimarães
entry.content:
Tema: Além da Migração S/4HANA: do Brownfield ao Clean Core
Data: 27/11 às 19h30

No nosso kick-off da SAP Community Belo Horizonte, teremos a honra de receber Alon Guimarães, Arquiteto de Soluções na Localiza & Co, para uma palestra que promete ir além da migração técnica e mostrar caminhos reais de evolução no ecossistema SAP: “Além da Migração S/4HANA: do Brownfield ao Clean Core.”

Em um cenário onde as empresas precisam tomar decisões críticas para simplificar processos e preparar o futuro, a jornada da Localiza & Co se torna um exemplo inspirador. Alon vai mostrar, de forma prática e acessível, como ocorreu a tomada de decisão na migração S/4HANA e como está acontecendo a evolução de Brownfield para a estratégia Clean Core – conectando escolhas estratégicas com resultados concretos. Uma palestra que vai além do discurso e traz aprendizados valiosos sobre como preparar o futuro no ecossistema SAP.

Sobre o palestrante

Alon Guimarães, Arquiteto de Soluções na Localiza & Co

Com mais de 15 anos de experiência em arquitetura de soluções SAP, integração de sistemas e liderança técnica, Alon se consolidou como referência em projetos de alta complexidade. Sua carreira é marcada pela capacidade de conectar tecnologia com estratégia de negócios, conduzindo transformações digitais que simplificam ambientes corporativos e preparam empresas para o futuro.

Na Localiza & Co, Alon foi o arquiteto responsável pela migração para o SAP S/4HANA, liderando decisões críticas e estruturando a evolução do modelo Brownfield para Clean Core. Hoje, atua como Arquiteto de Soluções e líder de transformação, guiando a empresa em sua jornada de modernização e inovação contínua no ecossistema SAP e no mindset Clean Core.

Principais destaques da carreira:

  • Liderança em projetos de migração para SAP S/4HANA;
  • Experiência em integração fiscal e monitoramento customizado;
  • Desenvolvimento de arquiteturas orientadas a jornadas ponta a ponta;
  • Atuação em iniciativas estratégicas para simplificação e governança de sistemas.

Por que você não pode perder?

Se você atua com SAP, arquitetura de soluções, integração de sistemas ou está envolvido em iniciativas de transformação digital, esta palestra é para você.

Vamos discutir como a Localiza & Co enfrentou decisões críticas na jornada de migração para o SAP S/4HANA, mostrando de forma prática e inspiradora:

  • Consequências de tomadas de decisões na migração S/4HANA para estratégia Clean Core
  • Os caminhos da evolução de Brownfield para a estratégia Clean Core
  • Lições valiosas para simplificar processos e preparar o futuro no ecossistema SAP
  • Estratégias para reduzir customizações e manter governança;
  • Boas práticas para preparar sua arquitetura para inovação contínua;
  • Insights sobre desafios reais e soluções práticas para empresas que estão nessa jornada.

Reserve na agenda:

  27/11/2025
  19h30
Kickoff da Comunidade SAP Belo Horizonte no Localiza Labs

entry.title: Re: SolMan 7.2 RFC unable to set to confirmed in producti...
entry.content:
The following comes from a document I created for my own use, are provided “as is”, with no claim of suitability to other customers’ situations. Solution Manager 7.2, ST support pack 18, was used as a reference. YMMV

The steps describe a new entry. The reader should be able to select and edit an existing entry rather than creating a new entry.

Navigation

/nSPRO > SAP Reference IMG

> SAP Solution Manager Implementation Guide

> SAP Solution Manager

> Capabilities (Optional)

> Change Control Management

> Change Request Management Framework

Make Settings for Change Transaction Types

 

Specify Required Status Values for Follow-Up Documents

Use this procedure to “define the statuses that follow-up documents (successor transactions) must have before a specific user status can be set for the current document.

“For the follow-up documents, Change Request Management action SET_PREDOC must be defined for this status so that the user status of the follow-up document can be set.”

[The above quoted text is from the SAP Reference IMG built-in documentation.]

For example, before an RFC can be set to Implemented, all related change documents (i.e., successor or follow-up documents) must be Completed or Withdrawn.

  1. In the Dialog Structure, select Create Transaction Types
    1. From the list, select the transaction type (of the predecessor document)
  2. In the Dialog Structure, select Specify Status Attributes
    1. From the list, select the User Status value (of the predecessor document)
      (hint: use the search help to view the status description)
  3. In the Dialog Structure, select Specify Required Status Values for Follow-Up Docs
  4. Select New Entry and enter the appropriate values:
    1. Transaction Type: Select the predecessor transaction type (document)
    2. Status Profile: Select the Status Profile
    3. User Status: Select the status value to which the predecessor transaction should be set.
    4. Select Save (select/create a transport request)
  5. Repeat to create new entries for all successor documents and statuses.

entry.title: Consuming the Free Open-Meteo Weather API Using ABAP – A Practical, Reusable OOP Approach
entry.content:
In many SAP teams, external API integration is still considered complex or “something middleware should handle”. But in reality, modern ABAP makes this easier than ever — especially when we take a clean OOP approach.

To demonstrate this, I built a simple, real-world example using the Open-Meteo weather API.
It’s absolutely free, requires no authentication, and returns clean JSON.

Example call:

Free Open-Meteo Weather API 

This makes it a perfect learning API for ABAP developers who want to practice:

  • HTTP calls

  • JSON parsing

  • OOP design patterns

  • Storing data into SAP tables

  • Clean, reusable architecture

In this article, I walk through the exact steps to build a production-friendly ABAP solution that reads weather data and stores it in a Z-table — using patterns that you can apply for ANY external REST API.

1. Business Use Case

You want to collect weather snapshots for specific locations, such as:

  • Seaport / airport operations

  • Logistics planning

  • Production environment monitoring

  • Shift planning during heavy rain conditions

  • Agricultural or outdoor operations

The Open-Meteo API provides:

  • Temperature

  • Windspeed

  • Wind direction

  • Weather code

  • Day/Night indicator

  • Timestamp

Our goal:

✔ Call Open-Meteo
✔ Parse JSON
✔ Map data into an ABAP structure
✔ Save a snapshot in a Z-table
✔ Use clean OOP architecture

2. Create Z-Table to Store Weather Data

Table: ZWEATHER_SNAP

Suggested fields:

Field Description

LOCATION_IDLogical location name
OBS_DATEDate from API
OBS_TIMETime from API
LATITUDE / LONGITUDECoordinates
TEMP_CTemperature
WINDSPEEDkm/h
WINDDIRwind direction (degrees)
WEATHERCODEAPI weather code
IS_DAYX / blank
CREATED_ON / CREATED_AT / CREATED_BYTechnical audit

Sample DDL:

@EndUserText.label: 'Weather snapshot from Open-Meteo'
define table zweather_snap {
  key mandt        : abap.clnt;
  key location_id  : abap.char(20);
  key obs_date     : abap.dats;
  key obs_time     : abap.tims;

  latitude         : abap.dec(8,5);
  longitude        : abap.dec(8,5);
  timezone         : abap.char(40);
  temp_c           : abap.dec(5,2);
  windspeed        : abap.dec(5,2);
  winddir          : abap.dec(5,1);
  weathercode      : abap.int4;
  is_day           : abap.char(1);

  created_on       : abap.dats;
  created_at       : abap.tims;
  created_by       : abap.uname;
}

3. Define ABAP Types for JSON Mapping

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_current_weather,
         temperature   TYPE decfloat16,
         windspeed     TYPE decfloat16,
         winddirection TYPE decfloat16,
         weathercode   TYPE i,
         is_day        TYPE abap_bool,
         time          TYPE string,
       END OF ty_current_weather.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_api_response,
         latitude               TYPE decfloat16,
         longitude              TYPE decfloat16,
         timezone               TYPE string,
         current_weather        TYPE ty_current_weather,
       END OF ty_api_response.

TYPES: BEGIN OF ty_weather_snapshot,
         location_id TYPE zweather_snap-location_id,
         obs_date    TYPE dats,
         obs_time    TYPE tims,
         latitude    TYPE zweather_snap-latitude,
         longitude   TYPE zweather_snap-longitude,
         timezone    TYPE zweather_snap-timezone,
         temp_c      TYPE zweather_snap-temp_c,
         windspeed   TYPE zweather_snap-windspeed,
         winddir     TYPE zweather_snap-winddir,
         weathercode TYPE zweather_snap-weathercode,
         is_day      TYPE zweather_snap-is_day,
       END OF ty_weather_snapshot.

4. Provider Interface (Strategy Pattern)

INTERFACE zif_weather_provider PUBLIC.
  METHODS get_current_weather
    IMPORTING
      iv_latitude  TYPE decfloat16
      iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
      iv_location  TYPE zweather_snap-location_id
    RETURNING VALUE(rs_weather) TYPE ty_weather_snapshot
    RAISING cx_root.
ENDINTERFACE.

This makes the design future-proof:
Tomorrow you can add other weather providers or internal REST services.

5. HTTP Authentication Helper (For Future APIs)

Open-Meteo does not require auth — but real APIs usually do.
This helper makes your next extension very easy.

CLASS zcl_http_auth_helper DEFINITION PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PRIVATE.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    CLASS-METHODS set_basic_auth
      IMPORTING io_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client
                iv_username TYPE string
                iv_password TYPE string.

    CLASS-METHODS set_bearer_auth
      IMPORTING io_http_client TYPE REF TO if_http_client
                iv_token TYPE string.
ENDCLASS.

6. Provider Class — Calling Open-Meteo

CLASS zcl_weather_open_meteo DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    INTERFACES zif_weather_provider.

  PRIVATE SECTION.
    CONSTANTS gc_base TYPE string VALUE
      'https://api.open-meteo.com/v1/forecast'.

    METHODS build_url
      IMPORTING iv_latitude  TYPE decfloat16
                iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
      RETURNING VALUE(rv_url) TYPE string.

    METHODS map_api_to_snapshot
      IMPORTING is_api TYPE ty_api_response
                iv_location TYPE zweather_snap-location_id
      RETURNING VALUE(rs_snap) TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.
ENDCLASS.

Provider Implementation

CLASS zcl_weather_open_meteo IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD zif_weather_provider~get_current_weather.
    DATA lo_http TYPE REF TO if_http_client.
    DATA lv_url TYPE string.
    DATA lv_json TYPE string.
    DATA ls_api TYPE ty_api_response.

    lv_url = build_url( iv_latitude = iv_latitude
                        iv_longitude = iv_longitude ).

    cl_http_client=>create_by_url(
      EXPORTING url = lv_url
      IMPORTING client = lo_http ).

    lo_http->request->set_method( 'GET' ).

    lo_http->send( ).
    lo_http->receive( ).

    lv_json = lo_http->response->get_cdata( ).

    /ui2/cl_json=>deserialize(
      EXPORTING json = lv_json
      CHANGING  data = ls_api ).

    rs_weather = map_api_to_snapshot(
                    is_api = ls_api
                    iv_location = iv_location ).
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD build_url.
    rv_url = |{ gc_base }?latitude={ iv_latitude }| &&
             |&longitude={ iv_longitude }| &&
             |&current_weather=true|.
  ENDMETHOD.


  METHOD map_api_to_snapshot.
    DATA lv_date TYPE string.
    DATA lv_time TYPE string.

    SPLIT is_api-current_weather-time AT 'T'
      INTO lv_date lv_time.

    REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF '-' IN lv_date WITH ''.
    REPLACE ALL OCCURRENCES OF ':' IN lv_time WITH ''.
    CONCATENATE lv_time '00' INTO lv_time.

    rs_snap-location_id = iv_location.
    rs_snap-latitude    = is_api-latitude.
    rs_snap-longitude   = is_api-longitude.
    rs_snap-timezone    = is_api-timezone.
    rs_snap-temp_c      = is_api-current_weather-temperature.
    rs_snap-windspeed   = is_api-current_weather-windspeed.
    rs_snap-winddir     = is_api-current_weather-winddirection.
    rs_snap-weathercode = is_api-current_weather-weathercode.
    rs_snap-is_day      = COND #( WHEN is_api-current_weather-is_day = abap_true THEN 'X' ELSE space ).

    rs_snap-obs_date = lv_date.
    rs_snap-obs_time = lv_time.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

7. Repository Class — Save to DB

CLASS zcl_weather_repository DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.
  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS save_snapshot
      IMPORTING is_snapshot TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.
ENDCLASS.

Implementation:

CLASS zcl_weather_repository IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD save_snapshot.
    DATA ls TYPE zweather_snap.
    MOVE-CORRESPONDING is_snapshot TO ls.

    ls-mandt      = sy-mandt.
    ls-created_on = sy-datum.
    ls-created_at = sy-uzeit.
    ls-created_by = sy-uname.

    INSERT zweather_snap FROM ls.
    IF sy-subrc <> 0.
      MODIFY zweather_snap FROM ls.
    ENDIF.
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

8. Application Service — Business Orchestration

CLASS zcl_weather_app_service DEFINITION
  PUBLIC FINAL CREATE PUBLIC.

  PUBLIC SECTION.
    METHODS constructor
      IMPORTING io_provider TYPE REF TO zif_weather_provider
                io_repo     TYPE REF TO zcl_weather_repository.

    METHODS collect_and_save
      IMPORTING iv_latitude TYPE decfloat16
                iv_longitude TYPE decfloat16
                iv_location TYPE zweather_snap-location_id.
ENDCLASS.

Implementation:

CLASS zcl_weather_app_service IMPLEMENTATION.

  METHOD constructor.
    me->io_provider = io_provider.
    me->io_repo = io_repo.
  ENDMETHOD.

  METHOD collect_and_save.
    DATA ls TYPE ty_weather_snapshot.

    ls = io_provider->get_current_weather(
      iv_latitude  = iv_latitude
      iv_longitude = iv_longitude
      iv_location  = iv_location ).

    io_repo->save_snapshot( ls ).
  ENDMETHOD.

ENDCLASS.

9. Executable Report

REPORT zweather_collector.

PARAMETERS:
  p_lat TYPE decfloat16 DEFAULT '6.9271' OBLIGATORY,
  p_lon TYPE decfloat16 DEFAULT '79.8612' OBLIGATORY,
  p_loc TYPE zweather_snap-location_id DEFAULT 'COLOMBO' OBLIGATORY.

DATA lo_service TYPE REF TO zcl_weather_app_service.

START-OF-SELECTION.

  lo_service = NEW zcl_weather_app_service(
                 io_provider = NEW zcl_weather_open_meteo( )
                 io_repo     = NEW zcl_weather_repository( ) ).

  TRY.
      lo_service->collect_and_save(
        iv_latitude  = p_lat
        iv_longitude = p_lon
        iv_location  = p_loc ).
      WRITE: / 'Weather snapshot saved for', p_loc.
    CATCH cx_root INTO DATA(lx).
      WRITE lx->get_text( ).
  ENDTRY.

10. Why This Pattern Is Better Than a One-Report Solution

✔ Clean separation of concerns

  • Provider → HTTP & JSON

  • Service → Business logic

  • Repository → DB operations

✔ Highly reusable

You can connect ANY API by creating a new provider.

✔ Future-proof for SAP BTP / ABAP Cloud

This layered design aligns with RAP & clean architecture.

✔ Easy to maintain

Each class is small and focuses on one task.

✔ Ready for automated jobs

You can run this via SM36 as a weather-collector batch job.

✔ Perfect teaching material

Developers learn clean OOP practices with a simple, real API.

11. Where You Can Extend This

  • Build a Fiori List Report to display weather history

  • Publish weather snapshots via an OData V4 service

  • Add multiple locations

  • Add token authentication for your next article

  • Add job scheduling every 30 minutes

  • Add charts using CDS Analytical Queries

12. Final Thoughts

This small Open-Meteo exercise demonstrates how modern ABAP can easily consume external REST APIs using clean OOP architecture.

More importantly, this pattern applies to any scenario:

  • IoT sensor readings

  • Machine temperature & vibration

  • Traffic or route optimization APIs

  • Currency exchange APIs

  • Cloud microservices

  • Internal REST systems

Once you build this pattern once, you can reuse it across your entire SAP landscape.

entry.title: Re: PO delivery time with icoterm
entry.content:
Hi , 

I understand your point. 

There is no separate transit time (from vendor to your plant). Assuming the planned lead time includes shipping time by the vendor in other INCO term cases, here in your case there is no shipping time. Technically, you are taking ownership of goods at vendor's location and hence your GR processing time starts here. 

If you do not want to do above, some organizations do not really post GR at this point of time and use 2 work arounds :

1. Use 103 (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant) movement types

2. Use Inbound Delivery (receipt at vendor) & 101 (receipt at plant 

In both the above cases, you need to include transit time in planned dely time. 

If you want to report transit time, you need to develop a report depending on which work around you used. 

Best regards, Ramki

--- Steps to Reproduce ---

--- Steps to Reproduce ---

  2. tested the following too: "Set the info update flag when the supplier number is filled.     "IF purchaseorderitem-suppliermaterialnumber IS NOT INITIAL.     "  IF purchaseorderitem_old-purchasinginforecordupdatecode IS INITIAL AND     "     purchaseorderitem-purchasinginforecordupdatecode IS INITIAL.     "     purchaseorderitemchange-purchasinginforecordupdatecode = 'A'.     "  ENDIF.     "ENDIF. 
  3. creation of purchase order without referenz to purchase requisition (worked)
  4. creation of purchase order with referenz to purchase requisition (not worked)

entry.title: Re: MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM - doesnt work - SAP Public C...
entry.content:
Dear Customer,

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the BAdI MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM does not influence the logic during Purchase Requisition (PR) → Purchase Order (PO) conversion.
As a result, the “Info Record Update” field remains empty when creating POs from PRs, even though it works correctly for manually created POs.

This is because PR-to-PO processing uses a different business context, and the BAdI you used is not called during this conversion step.

Root Cause

The PR-to-PO process runs in a controlled workflow where MM_PUR_S4_PO_MODIFY_ITEM is bypassed.
Therefore, any custom logic implemented in this BAdI will not be executed during PR conversion, which is why the Info Record Update flag is not defaulted automatically.

Resolution Overview

To ensure consistent behavior, you need to use the BAdI that is actually triggered for all PO creation modes—including conversions from PRs.

The correct BAdI for this scenario in Public Cloud is:

BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO

This BAdI is executed just before the PO is saved, making it reliable across manual creation, PR conversion, and automated processes.

The issue is caused by using a BAdI that does not participate in the PR-to-PO process.
Switching to BD_MMPUR_FINAL_CHECK_PO provides a reliable, Public Cloud–compliant solution that ensures the “Info Record Update” field is always set during all types of PO creation.

 

Extensibility for Purchase Order Apps

Best Regards'

Aishwarya
